required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy of Brooke Bond Black Tea Extract on Flow Mediated Dilation in Indian Males
clinical_study.official_title: Efficacy of Standardized Brooke Bond Black Tea Extract on Flow-Mediated Dilation After an Acute Dose as Well as After One Week of Consumption in Healthy Adult Indian Males

collaborator.agency: Lotus Labs Pvt. Ltd, Bangalore, India

brief_summary.textblock: This study examines the effect of 1800 mg/day standardized Brooke Bond black tea extract, equivalent to 400 mg flavonoids, on Flow Mediated Dilation in healthy Indian males.

detailed_description.textblock: Flow mediated dilation (FMD) is a non-invasive measurement technique performed using ultrasound equipment to measure hyperaemia induced dilation of blood vessels. Evidence from prospective studies suggests that FMD is independently inversely associated with cardiovascular events.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline day 1 to 2 hours post consumption on day 8.
primary_outcome.description: Change in flow mediated dilation (FMD) due to tea consumption when compared to control. FMD measurement included the following steps: 1 minute base scan to measure the baseline diameter of artery (baseline) 5 minutes of forearm occlusion at 300±30 mmHg, just below the elbow 2-5 cm from antecubital crease 4 minutes FMD scan, which started immediately after release of the occlusion (reactive hyperaemia stage) FMD was calculated as maximal percentage change in diameter of the artery above the baseline value after the release of the occlusion

secondary_outcome.measure: Acute Effect of Tea vs Control
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline on day 1 to 2 hours post consumption on day 1
secondary_outcome.description: Change in flow mediated dilation due to tea consumption when compared to control. FMD measurement included the following steps: 1 minute base scan to measure the baseline diameter of artery (baseline) 5 minutes of forearm occlusion at 300±30 mmHg, just below the elbow 2-5 cm from antecubital crease 4 minutes FMD scan, which started immediately after release of the occlusion (reactive hyperaemia stage) FMD was calculated as maximal percentage change in diameter of the artery above the baseline value after the release of the occlusion

secondary_outcome.measure: Chronic Effect of Tea vs Control
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline at day 1 to baseline on day 8
secondary_outcome.description: Change in flow mediated dilation (FMD) due to tea consumption when compared to control. FMD measurement included the following steps: 1 minute base scan to measure the baseline diameter of artery (baseline) 5 minutes of forearm occlusion at 300±30 mmHg, just below the elbow 2-5 cm from antecubital crease 4 minutes FMD scan, which started immediately after release of the occlusion (reactive hyperaemia stage) FMD was calculated as maximal percentage change in diameter of the artery above the baseline value after the release of the occlusion

arm_group.description: Nutrition intervention study with a control
Nutrition intervention study with a black tea extract

intervention.intervention_name: Nutrition intervention study with a black tea extract
intervention.description: Tea extract: 1800 mg/day standardized Brooke Bond black tea extract equivalent to 400 mg flavonoids dissolved in 240 ml hot water. Products will be consumed for 8 days. On measurement days tea will be given to the subjects as a single acute dose and 2 grams of sugar will be added. On day 2-7 subjects will consume 3 cups or tea, each prepared with 800 mg product in 80 ml of boiling water and sugar added to subject's taste. First cup of tea will be taken as morning tea, 2nd at breakfast and 3rd in the evening. No milk will be added.

intervention.intervention_name: Nutrition intervention study with a control
intervention.description: Control: 1800 mg/day of a powder that gives a flavoured beverage with a color similar to black tea dissolved in 240 ml hot water. Products will be consumed for 8 days. On measurement days control will be given to the subjects as a single acute dose and 2 grams of sugar will be added. On day 2-7 subjects will consume 3 cups of control, each prepared with 800 mg product in 80 ml of boiling water and sugar added to subject's taste. First cup of tea will be taken as morning tea, 2nd at breakfast and 3rd in the evening. No milk will be added.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Male volunteers aged between >_30 _< 50 years of age
- Body Mass Index (BMI) of >_18 and _< 25.0 kg/m2
- Systolic blood pressure >_140 and >_100 mmHg and diastolic blood pressure < 90 and > 70 mmHg
- Subjects who consume _< 2 cups of coffee per day
- Subjects who drink tea regularly (>_ 2 cups per day)
- Apparently healthy, with no reported medical condition which might affect the assessment as judged by the study physician or/and PI
- No prescribed medical treatment that may affect study parameters as judged by the Study Physician
- Subject willing to abstain from alcohol on day before and on the day of assessment
- Willing to sign the informed consent form
Exclusion Criteria:
- Smokers and/or tobacco chewers
- Those who consume regular alcohol (> 160 ml of alcohol per week)
- Reported intense sport activities > 10h/week
- Participating in any other clinical study concurrently or if participated in any study during 2 months preceding the screening visit

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Forty five subjects were invited for screening. Two subjects did not come for the screening, three subjects were not willing to participate and three subjects did not fulfil the inclusion criteria. Of the 37 subjects that fulfilled all inclusion an exclusion criteria 30 were invited to participate.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Thirty subjects meeting all criteria were randomised over the two arms

group.title: Control, Then Washout, Then Tea
group.description: Subjects first received Control for one week with Flow Mediated Dilation (FMD) measurements on day 1 and day 8. After a washout of one week (day 8-15) they received Tea for one week with FMD measurements at day 16 and day 22. All FMD measurements were done in a fasted state just before test product intake and exactly 2 hours after test product intake.

group.title: Tea, Then Wash Out, Then Control
group.description: Subjects first received Tea for one week with with Flow Mediated Dilation (FMD) measurements on day 1 and day 8. After a washout of one week (day 8-15) they received Control for one week with FMD measurements at day 16 and day 22. All FMD measurements were done in a fasted state just before test product intake and exactly 2 hours after test product intake.

outcome.title: 'Acute-upon-chronic Effect' of Tea vs Control
outcome.description: Change in flow mediated dilation (FMD) due to tea consumption when compared to control. FMD measurement included the following steps: 1 minute base scan to measure the baseline diameter of artery (baseline) 5 minutes of forearm occlusion at 300±30 mmHg, just below the elbow 2-5 cm from antecubital crease 4 minutes FMD scan, which started immediately after release of the occlusion (reactive hyperaemia stage) FMD was calculated as maximal percentage change in diameter of the artery above the baseline value after the release of the occlusion
outcome.time_frame: Baseline day 1 to 2 hours post consumption on day 8.
outcome.population: Per protocol based on the full data set excluding one subject who did produce relevant data (AE) and three subjects who were removed during blind review (operator comments, hypertension and increase in body weight). Single data points were removed for 6 subjects (all single data points) based on operator comments.

measure.title: 'Acute-upon-chronic Effect' of Tea vs Control
measure.description: Change in flow mediated dilation (FMD) due to tea consumption when compared to control. FMD measurement included the following steps: 1 minute base scan to measure the baseline diameter of artery (baseline) 5 minutes of forearm occlusion at 300±30 mmHg, just below the elbow 2-5 cm from antecubital crease 4 minutes FMD scan, which started immediately after release of the occlusion (reactive hyperaemia stage) FMD was calculated as maximal percentage change in diameter of the artery above the baseline value after the release of the occlusion
measure.population: Per protocol based on the full data set excluding one subject who did produce relevant data (AE) and three subjects who were removed during blind review (operator comments, hypertension and increase in body weight). Single data points were removed for 6 subjects (all single data points) based on operator comments.

analysis.groups_desc: Null hypothesis: no difference between Tea and Control.
analysis.method_desc: Subject as random factor, baseline same period and mean baseline in both periods as covariates, and treatment, operator, and period as fixed effects.

group.title: Tea Extract
group.description: Subjects when they consumed tea extract for one week

group.title: Control
group.description: Subjects when they consumed control for one week

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Subjects when they consumed placebo for 6 days during the run in and during 7 days during the washout

event.description: Subject developed hypertension after being included

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
